articles.title: EU Recovery Plan: An additional 516 million euros for Austria
articles.summary: Austria has already received 84 percent of its funds from the EU Recovery Plan of NextGenerationEU. The total amount of around four billion euros is to be reached by 2026.
articles.content:
Austria has already received 84 percent of its funds from the EU Recovery Plan of NextGenerationEU. The total amount of around four billion euros is to be reached by 2026.

Brussels (APA) – The EU Commission approved the disbursement of 515.5 million euros under the NextGenerationEU recovery plan to Austria on Wednesday. The application includes reforms such as improving working conditions in long-term care, a repair bonus program, and investments in 17,500 photovoltaic systems on residential buildings. The Austrian recovery plan, which amounts to around four billion euros, has achieved a disbursement rate of 84 percent.

As a result, the funds disbursed to Austria under the Recovery and Resilience Facility amount to 3.33 billion euros, including 492 million euros in pre-financing, according to the EU Commission. This amount corresponds to 84 percent of all funds provided for in the Austrian plan, with 74 percent of all planned milestones and targets having been achieved. The total sum of around four billion euros for Austria is to be disbursed in the form of grants by 2026. These are performance-based.

So-called “milestones” and “target values” must be achieved; Austria must accomplish 171 by 2026. With the first payment request, 44 targets have already been ticked off. 1.15 billion euros went to 27 reform and 32 investment projects, focusing on sustainability and digitalization, but also social and cultural accents. The second payment request of 1.6 billion euros concerned reforms aimed at supporting investment initiatives in the areas of digitalization, health, pensions, taxation, and phasing out fossil heating systems.

The goal is a more sustainable and crisis-resistant Europe

The Recovery and Resilience Facility was created to support Europe in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is the centerpiece of the recovery instrument NextGenerationEU. According to the Commission, the fundamental goal is to make Europe more sustainable, digital, and crisis-resistant. A total of up to 672.5 billion euros (at 2018 prices) is to flow to support investments and reforms. Of this, 312.5 billion euros are earmarked for grants and 360 billion euros for loans. (26.11.2025)

The story has clear substance and meaningful positive real-world impact for society.

articles.title: Massive prehistoric structure found near Stonehenge
articles.summary: A study has confirmed 16 pits were dug close to the Stonehenge more than 4,000 years ago.
articles.content:
Massive prehistoric structure found near Stonehenge

22 hours ago Share Save Sophie Parker Wiltshire Share Save

Internet Archaeology journal The pits were found with geophysics, then boreholes were made to test the sediment.

The discovery of a series of huge Neolithic pits have been confirmed at the Stonehenge World Heritage Site after initial research a few years ago. The massive pits at Durrington Walls in Wiltshire are set at regular intervals, ten metres in diameter and more than five metres deep. Professor Vince Gaffney said that as a "cohesive structure" they could be "one of the largest prehistoric structures in Britain, if not the largest prehistoric structure". The new research has been published in the Internet Archaeology Journal and concludes pits are almost certainly man-made and more than 4,000 years old.

Historic England Archive/Heritage Images via Getty Images Durrington Walls sits next to Woodhenge in the Stonehenge landscape

Prof Gaffney, from the University of Bradford, explained it would have taken a lot of effort to dig the holes - around two storeys deep - from the chalk landscape. The horseshoe-shaped pits also link to another monument near Larkhill. "The circle is pretty accurate. It suggests that people were pacing the distances out to make sure that the pits were aligned at the same distance all the way around as the distance from the henge to the earlier enclosure" he said. Prof Gaffney said it added to previous evidence that people were counting and applying it. "They're inscribing something about their cosmology, their belief systems, into the earth itself in a very dramatic way."

Researchers had surveyed 12 sq km (7.4 sq m) of the landscape when they spotted the giant holes. No longer visible to the naked eye and too big to realistically excavate very quickly, they made narrow boreholes to take samples of the material from the features.

Internet Archaeology journal Experts analysed sediment from the pits to date them

DNA extracted from the samples revealed remains of animals, including sheep and cattle. The samples also helped experts date the excavations. Dr Tim Kinnaird from the University of St Andrews called it a "super henge" and used a method called luminescence dating: "So just before that sediment falls into the pit, it's exposed to daylight, so we can date the time of construction." It also revealed they were kept open for 1,000 years: "So that spans changing cultures," he explained.

articles.personality_title: Huge prehistoric pits discovered near Stonehenge
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Stonehenge is a famous ancient site in England known for its large stone circle. Nearby, there are other ancient monuments, but many parts of this landscape are still being studied to learn more about prehistoric people.

**What happened** – Researchers have confirmed the discovery of 16 large pits near Stonehenge at a place called Durrington Walls. These pits are about 10 meters wide and over 5 meters deep, arranged in a horseshoe shape. Scientists used special tools to find the pits underground and took samples from narrow holes to study the soil and remains inside.

**Impact** – The pits are over 4,000 years old and may form one of the largest prehistoric structures in Britain. They show that ancient people carefully measured and planned these holes, possibly linking them to their beliefs about the world. The pits were kept open for around 1,000 years, showing their long importance in ancient culture.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue studying the pits and the surrounding area to learn more about how and why they were made. This could reveal new details about the lives and beliefs of the people who lived near Stonehenge thousands of years ago.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A series of huge, carefully planned pits near Stonehenge reveal a major prehistoric structure that deepens understanding of ancient human culture.
articles.personality_title_fr: De grands fosses préhistoriques découvertes près de Stonehenge
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Stonehenge est un site ancien célèbre en Angleterre, connu pour son grand cercle de pierres. À proximité, il existe d'autres monuments anciens, mais beaucoup de parties de ce paysage sont encore étudiées pour mieux comprendre les peuples préhistoriques.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont confirmé la découverte de 16 grandes fosses près de Stonehenge, à un endroit appelé Durrington Walls. Ces fosses mesurent environ 10 mètres de large et plus de 5 mètres de profondeur, disposées en forme de fer à cheval. Les scientifiques ont utilisé des outils spéciaux pour les trouver sous terre et ont prélevé des échantillons dans de petits trous pour étudier le sol et les restes à l'intérieur.

**Impact** – Les fosses ont plus de 4 000 ans et pourraient former l'une des plus grandes structures préhistoriques de Grande-Bretagne. Elles montrent que les anciens planifiaient et mesuraient soigneusement ces trous, peut-être en lien avec leurs croyances sur le monde. Les fosses sont restées ouvertes pendant environ 1 000 ans, ce qui montre leur importance dans la culture ancienne.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront d'étudier ces fosses et la zone autour pour mieux comprendre comment et pourquoi elles ont été creusées. Cela pourrait révéler de nouveaux détails sur la vie et les croyances des habitants proches de Stonehenge il y a des milliers d'années.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une série de grandes fosses soigneusement planifiées près de Stonehenge révèle une importante structure préhistorique qui enrichit la compréhension de la culture humaine ancienne.
articles.personality_title_es: Grandes fosas prehistóricas descubiertas cerca de Stonehenge
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Stonehenge es un sitio antiguo famoso en Inglaterra, conocido por su gran círculo de piedras. Cerca de allí hay otros monumentos antiguos, pero muchas partes de este paisaje aún se estudian para aprender más sobre las personas prehistóricas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores confirmaron el hallazgo de 16 grandes fosas cerca de Stonehenge, en un lugar llamado Durrington Walls. Estas fosas tienen unos 10 metros de ancho y más de 5 metros de profundidad, dispuestas en forma de herradura. Los científicos usaron herramientas especiales para encontrarlas bajo tierra y tomaron muestras de pequeños pozos para estudiar el suelo y los restos dentro.

**Impacto** – Las fosas tienen más de 4,000 años y podrían formar una de las estructuras prehistóricas más grandes de Gran Bretaña. Muestran que las personas antiguas planificaron y midieron cuidadosamente estos huecos, posiblemente relacionados con sus creencias sobre el mundo. Las fosas permanecieron abiertas durante alrededor de 1,000 años, mostrando su importancia en la cultura antigua.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán estudiando las fosas y el área cercana para entender mejor cómo y por qué fueron hechas. Esto podría revelar nuevos detalles sobre la vida y las creencias de las personas que vivieron cerca de Stonehenge hace miles de años.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una serie de grandes fosas cuidadosamente planificadas cerca de Stonehenge revela una estructura prehistórica importante que profundiza la comprensión de la cultura humana antigua.
